page.title: 01TOMINTOUL
page.content: Tomintoul, 1,150 feet up on the remote moors of the southern end of Moray District,is the highest village in the Highlands.The village was founded in 1776 by the fourth Duke of Gordon. It is laid out along a gentle ridge with the River Avon on one side and the Conglass Water on the other side.The present day population is around 340 and the village is a popular centre for tourists, anglers, and skiers.At the heart of the village there is a spacious square with a green. Amongst the facilities available for visitors are 4 hotels, youth hostel, outdoor centre, tourist information office and museum, ponytrekking centre,pottery shop, weaver's shop and a woodcarver's shop.Tomintoul is also on the Malt Whisky Trail with the village shop stocking a large selection of malts and blends.
